elements.content: Two stable Zn-cluster-based MOFs, [Zn9(btz)12(atdbc)3(DMF)]·3DMF·12H2O (compound 1, Hbtz = 1H-benzotriazole, H2atdbc = 4,4′-(4-amino-1,2,4-triazol-3,5-diyl)­dibenzoic acid, DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide) and [Zn4(btz)6(bcpt)]·3DMF (compound 2, H2bcpt = 3,5-bis­(4′-carboxy-phenyl)-1,2,4-triazole), have been successfully constructed by adopting the mixed ligands approach. Both the compounds exhibit high chemical stability under aqueous solution and common organic solvents. Especially, compounds 1 and 2 can be stable in pH = 2 and pH = 12 solutions. Meanwhile, compound 1 exhibits good ability to selectively separate CO2 from CH4. CO2 over CH4 selectivity is 5.2 (0.5/0.5) and 5.7 (0.05/0.95) at 298 K under 1 bar, respectively, which may be used for the separation of gases in industrial applications. Moreover, compound 1 displays breathing behavior for small-molecule gases (N2, CO2, C2H6, and C3H8), and compound 2 only exhibits the same phenomenon for CO2 adsorption because of its ultramicroporous channels.
elements.clean_text: Two stable Zn-cluster-based MOFs, [Zn9(btz)12(atdbc)3(DMF)]⋅3DMF⋅12H2O (compound 1, Hbtz = 1H-benzotriazole, H2atdbc = 4,4'-(4-amino-1,2,4-triazol-3,5-diyl)dibenzoic acid, DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide) and [Zn4(btz)6(bcpt)]⋅3DMF (compound 2, H2bcpt = 3,5-bis(4'-carboxy-phenyl)-1,2,4-triazole), have been successfully constructed by adopting the mixed ligands approach. Both the compounds exhibit high chemical stability under aqueous solution and common organic solvents. Especially, compounds 1 and 2 can be stable in pH = 2 and pH = 12 solutions. Meanwhile, compound 1 exhibits good ability to selectively separate CO2 from CH4. CO2 over CH4 selectivity is 5.2 (0.5/0.5) and 5.7 (0.05/0.95) at 298 K under 1 bar, respectively, which may be used for the separation of gases in industrial applications. Moreover, compound 1 displays breathing behavior for small-molecule gases (N2, CO2, C2H6, and C3H8), and compound 2 only exhibits the same phenomenon for CO2 adsorption because of its ultramicroporous channels.

elements.content: Two stable metal−organic frameworks have been constructed based on Zn clusters by using the mixed ligands strategy, which show high thermal and chemical stability. Both the compounds exhibit breathing behavior, in particular, compound 1 possesses good selectivity for CO2 over CH4.
elements.clean_text: Two stable metal-organic frameworks have been constructed based on Zn clusters by using the mixed ligands strategy, which show high thermal and chemical stability. Both the compounds exhibit breathing behavior, in particular, compound 1 possesses good selectivity for CO2 over CH4.

elements.content: In recent years, environmental and energy problems have become hot issues. As the primary cause of the greenhouse effect, CO2 is seriously affecting human life. Therefore, effective control of the concentration of CO2 in the atmosphere has attracted the attention of scientists around the world. In order to solve the problem, one way is to reduce its artificial emissions; another way is to use porous adsorbents to capture CO2. As we all know, natural gas is mainly composed of CH4, which is a clean energy source, and also contains a small quantity of CO2. From an energy perspective, the presence of CO2 will reduce its energy conversion rate, so it is meaningful and challenging to achieve efficient separation of CO2 from methane.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In recent years, environmental and energy problems have become hot issues. As the primary cause of the greenhouse effect, CO2 is seriously affecting human life. Therefore, effective control of the concentration of CO2 in the atmosphere has attracted the attention of scientists around the world. In order to solve the problem, one way is to reduce its artificial emissions; another way is to use porous adsorbents to capture CO2. As we all know, natural gas is mainly composed of CH4, which is a clean energy source, and also contains a small quantity of CO2. From an energy perspective, the presence of CO2 will reduce its energy conversion rate, so it is meaningful and challenging to achieve efficient separation of CO2 from methane.

elements.content: With the deepening of research, porous metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) with high surface area and tunable pore sizes have shown their advantages over the conventional carbon-based materials and porous zeolites in some fields and have exhibited outstanding properties in terms of gas storage and selective separation, catalysis, luminescence sensing, and proton conduction. As is well-known, water stability is a fundamental characteristic for any material used in practical application because large amounts of water exist in industrial production, storage, and application. However, most of reported MOFs are unable to contact water molecules because of the fragility of metal–ligand bonds, such as MOF-5, which greatly limits these MOFs’ practical application. Up to now, water-stable MOFs have attracted much attention among the scientific community, and their related publications are greatly increasing.
elements.clean_text: With the deepening of research, porous metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with high surface area and tunable pore sizes have shown their advantages over the conventional carbon-based materials and porous zeolites in some fields and have exhibited outstanding properties in terms of gas storage and selective separation, catalysis, luminescence sensing, and proton conduction. As is well-known, water stability is a fundamental characteristic for any material used in practical application because large amounts of water exist in industrial production, storage, and application. However, most of reported MOFs are unable to contact water molecules because of the fragility of metal-ligand bonds, such as MOF-5, which greatly limits these MOFs' practical application. Up to now, water-stable MOFs have attracted much attention among the scientific community, and their related publications are greatly increasing.

elements.content: Generally, the MOF structure will emerge with phase change and structural decomposition under a water environment because of their sensitivity to water molecules. Water-stable MOFs usually possess the following structure characteristics: (1) high-valence metal carboxylate frameworks, such as Zr-based MOFs, Al-based MIL-121, In-based JLU-Liu18; (2) azolate-based MOFs, such as zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs); (3) MOFs with blocked metal ions, which are not vulnerable to water molecules. (4) some Cu- or Zn-based MOFs with Cu–N or Zn–N bonding. On the basis of the abovementioned four types of structural features, a large number of water-stable MOFs have been reported and used in proton conduction under certain humidity, sensing, and catalysis in the aqueous phase. Taking into account the abovementioned aspects, the azolate ligand Hbtz (1H-benzotriazole) is chosen to construct metal-chain SBUs and [Zn9] clusters, the linear ligands 4,4′-(4-amino-1,2,4-triazol-3,5-diyl)­dibenzoic acid (H2atdbc) and 3,5-bis­(4′-carboxy-phenyl)-1,2,4-triazole (H2bcpt) are selected to assemble the three-dimensional (3D) frameworks by further connecting the Zn cluster. As a result, we successfully synthesized two novel water-stable MOFs: [Zn9(btz)12(atdbc)3(DMF)]·3DMF·12H2O (compound 1) and [Zn4(btz)6(bcpt)]·3DMF (compound 2). Because of the presence of the azolate Hbtz ligand, compounds 1 and 2 possess the [Zn9(btz)12] cluster and [Zn4(btz)6] rod SBUs, respectively. Both compounds exhibit excellent chemical and water stability. In addition, compound 1 exhibits the breathing behavior and efficient separation of small gases. At 77 K, ultra-microporous compound 2 has no adsorption ability for N2, but shows a step-by-step adsorption for CO2 at 195 K. At 298 K and 1 bar, through the ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST), the selectivity of CO2 and small molecule hydrocarbon over CH4 for compound 1 were predicted.
elements.clean_text: Generally, the MOF structure will emerge with phase change and structural decomposition under a water environment because of their sensitivity to water molecules. Water-stable MOFs usually possess the following structure characteristics: (1) high-valence metal carboxylate frameworks, such as Zr-based MOFs, Al-based MIL-121, In-based JLU-Liu18; (2) azolate-based MOFs, such as zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs); (3) MOFs with blocked metal ions, which are not vulnerable to water molecules. (4) some Cu- or Zn-based MOFs with Cu-N or Zn-N bonding. On the basis of the abovementioned four types of structural features, a large number of water-stable MOFs have been reported and used in proton conduction under certain humidity, sensing, and catalysis in the aqueous phase. Taking into account the abovementioned aspects, the azolate ligand Hbtz (1H-benzotriazole) is chosen to construct metal-chain SBUs and [Zn9] clusters, the linear ligands 4,4'-(4-amino-1,2,4-triazol-3,5-diyl)dibenzoic acid (H2atdbc) and 3,5-bis(4'-carboxy-phenyl)-1,2,4-triazole (H2bcpt) are selected to assemble the three-dimensional (3D) frameworks by further connecting the Zn cluster. As a result, we successfully synthesized two novel water-stable MOFs: [Zn9(btz)12(atdbc)3(DMF)]⋅3DMF⋅12H2O (compound 1) and [Zn4(btz)6(bcpt)]⋅3DMF (compound 2). Because of the presence of the azolate Hbtz ligand, compounds 1 and 2 possess the [Zn9(btz)12] cluster and [Zn4(btz)6] rod SBUs, respectively. Both compounds exhibit excellent chemical and water stability. In addition, compound 1 exhibits the breathing behavior and efficient separation of small gases. At 77 K, ultra-microporous compound 2 has no adsorption ability for N2, but shows a step-by-step adsorption for CO2 at 195 K. At 298 K and 1 bar, through the ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST), the selectivity of CO2 and small molecule hydrocarbon over CH4 for compound 1 were predicted.

elements.content: The reactants and reagents were purchased from commercial sources and used in experiments without any treatment. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were taken on a Rigaku D/max-2550 diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) at room temperature. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were tested on a TGA Q500 thermoanalyzer from 25 to 800 °C under air atmosphere. C, H, and N elemental analyses were carried out on a Vario MICRO elementar (Germany). The measurements of N2 gas adsorption were tested on a Micromeritics ASAP 2420 instrument. The measurements of CO2 and hydrocarbon gas adsorption were tested on a Micromeritics 3-Flex instrument.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

The reactants and reagents were purchased from commercial sources and used in experiments without any treatment. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were taken on a Rigaku D/max-2550 diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) at room temperature. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were tested on a TGA Q500 thermoanalyzer from 25 to 800 °C under air atmosphere. C, H, and N elemental analyses were carried out on a Vario MICRO elementar (Germany). The measurements of N2 gas adsorption were tested on a Micromeritics ASAP 2420 instrument. The measurements of CO2 and hydrocarbon gas adsorption were tested on a Micromeritics 3-Flex instrument.

elements.content: The mixture of zinc nitrate hexahydrate (13.6 mg, 0.045 mmol), Hbtz (11 mg, 0.092 mmol), H2atdbc (5 mg, 0.015 mmol), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) (1 mL) and acetic acid (15 μL) was placed in a tightly capped 10 mL vial, then heated at 85 °C for 12 h and 105 °C for 1 day. Colorless block crystals were obtained and immersed in fresh DMF and desiccated under air conditions [yield 60% based on zinc nitrate hexahydrate]. Elemental analysis (wt %) for compound 1: calcd: C, 45.6; H, 3.7; N, 21.0. Found: C, 46.0; H, 3.5; N, 20.9.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Compound 1 

The mixture of zinc nitrate hexahydrate (13.6 mg, 0.045 mmol), Hbtz (11 mg, 0.092 mmol), H2atdbc (5 mg, 0.015 mmol), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) (1 mL) and acetic acid (15 μL) was placed in a tightly capped 10 mL vial, then heated at 85 °C for 12 h and 105 °C for 1 day. Colorless block crystals were obtained and immersed in fresh DMF and desiccated under air conditions [yield 60% based on zinc nitrate hexahydrate]. Elemental analysis (wt %) for compound 1: calcd: C, 45.6; H, 3.7; N, 21.0. Found: C, 46.0; H, 3.5; N, 20.9.

elements.content: The mixture of zinc nitrate hexahydrate (14 mg, 0.047 mmol), Hbtz (22 mg, 0.184 mmol), H2bcpt (5 mg, 0.016 mmol), DMF (1 mL), and acetic acid (20 μL) was placed in a tightly capped 10 mL vial, then heated at 85 °C for 12 h and 105 °C for 3 days. Colorless block crystals were obtained and immersed in fresh DMF and desiccated under air conditions [yield 60% based on zinc nitrate hexahydrate]. Elemental analysis (wt %) for compound 2: calcd: C, 48.9; H, 3.6; N, 22.4. Found: C, 48.8; H, 3.5; N, 22.3.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Compound 2 

The mixture of zinc nitrate hexahydrate (14 mg, 0.047 mmol), Hbtz (22 mg, 0.184 mmol), H2bcpt (5 mg, 0.016 mmol), DMF (1 mL), and acetic acid (20 μL) was placed in a tightly capped 10 mL vial, then heated at 85 °C for 12 h and 105 °C for 3 days. Colorless block crystals were obtained and immersed in fresh DMF and desiccated under air conditions [yield 60% based on zinc nitrate hexahydrate]. Elemental analysis (wt %) for compound 2: calcd: C, 48.9; H, 3.6; N, 22.4. Found: C, 48.8; H, 3.5; N, 22.3.

elements.content: Two structures of compounds 1 and 2 were both obtained on a Bruker Apex II CCD single crystal diffractometer with a graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293(2) K. Both structures were determined by direct methods and refined using the SHELXL-2014 program. All nonhydrogen atoms were determined by the anisotropical technology. During the final refinement, there exist some high-electron density Q peaks in the cavities for two structures, which are attributed to free solvent molecules. Thus, both structures are treated with the SQUEEZE routine. According to the crystallographic data, elements and TGA data, the final formula of two compounds was derived. The CCDC number is 1850322 and 1850323 for compounds 1 and 2, respectively. Topology information was obtained using TOPOS 4.0. The related crystal data are listed in Table S1, and bond lengths and angles are listed in Tables S2 and S3.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Two structures of compounds 1 and 2 were both obtained on a Bruker Apex II CCD single crystal diffractometer with a graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293(2) K. Both structures were determined by direct methods and refined using the SHELXL-2014 program. All nonhydrogen atoms were determined by the anisotropical technology. During the final refinement, there exist some high-electron density Q peaks in the cavities for two structures, which are attributed to free solvent molecules. Thus, both structures are treated with the SQUEEZE routine. According to the crystallographic data, elements and TGA data, the final formula of two compounds was derived. The CCDC number is 1850322 and 1850323 for compounds 1 and 2, respectively. Topology information was obtained using TOPOS 4.0. The related crystal data are listed in Table S1, and bond lengths and angles are listed in Tables S2 and S3.

elements.content: The crystal structural analysis shows that compound 1 crystallizes in triclinic space group P1̅. The consistency between the PXRD pattern of synthesized and simulated compound 1 confirms that the synthesized sample is in pure phase (Figure S2, Supporting Information). As expected, compound 1 is composed of [Zn9(btz)12] SBUs, which is formed by twelve btz– ligands (a). Up to now, MOFs based on [Zn9] SBUs have been rarely reported. From the structural point of view, nine zinc atoms are chelated by nitrogen atoms from btz– ligands to form the [Zn9(btz)12] cluster, which are further bridged by atdbc2– ligands to assemble the 2-fold interpenetrated 3D framework (b). Although the framework’s pore size becomes narrow due to the interpenetration of the structure, it still exists as a small one-dimensional (1D) channel (4.1 Å × 4.3 Å) exclusive of van der Waals radius (d). Topological analysis showed that the [Zn9(btz)12] cluster is regarded as a 7-connected node with a distorted decahedron, ligand H2atdbc can be regarded as the 2- and 3-connected node. Hence, the 2-fold interpenetrated framework of compound 1 can be described as a new (3,7) connected topology with a Schläfli symbol of {3·52}­{32·44·57·68} (c,e). The PLATON calculation indicates that the total solvent-accessible volume of compound 1 is 8459 Å3, which accounts for about 38.9% per unit cell volume.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structure Descriptions

The crystal structural analysis shows that compound 1 crystallizes in triclinic space group P1̅. The consistency between the PXRD pattern of synthesized and simulated compound 1 confirms that the synthesized sample is in pure phase (Figure S2, Supporting Information). As expected, compound 1 is composed of [Zn9(btz)12] SBUs, which is formed by twelve btz- ligands (a). Up to now, MOFs based on [Zn9] SBUs have been rarely reported. From the structural point of view, nine zinc atoms are chelated by nitrogen atoms from btz- ligands to form the [Zn9(btz)12] cluster, which are further bridged by atdbc2- ligands to assemble the 2-fold interpenetrated 3D framework (b). Although the framework's pore size becomes narrow due to the interpenetration of the structure, it still exists as a small one-dimensional (1D) channel (4.1 Å × 4.3 Å) exclusive of van der Waals radius (d). Topological analysis showed that the [Zn9(btz)12] cluster is regarded as a 7-connected node with a distorted decahedron, ligand H2atdbc can be regarded as the 2- and 3-connected node. Hence, the 2-fold interpenetrated framework of compound 1 can be described as a new (3,7) connected topology with a Schläfli symbol of {3⋅52}{32⋅44⋅57⋅68} (c,e). The PLATON calculation indicates that the total solvent-accessible volume of compound 1 is 8459 Å3, which accounts for about 38.9% per unit cell volume.

elements.content: Description of compound 1: (a) [Zn9] clusters viewed as a 7-connected node with a distorted decahedron, the ligand viewed as the 2- and 3-connected node; (b) the 2-fold interpenetrated framework; (c) polyhedral view of the 2-fold interpenetrated framework; (d) CPK model of the channel via Y axis; (e) topological illustration displayed by tiling.
elements.clean_text: 1  Description of compound 1: (a) [Zn9] clusters viewed as a 7-connected node with a distorted decahedron, the ligand viewed as the 2- and 3-connected node; (b) the 2-fold interpenetrated framework; (c) polyhedral view of the 2-fold interpenetrated framework; (d) CPK model of the channel via Y axis; (e) topological illustration displayed by tiling.

elements.content: Compound 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system with the Cc space group. PXRD patterns indicate the phase purity of the synthesized sample (Figure S2, Supporting Information). Unlike compound 1, structural analysis shows that there are 1D zigzag ladder [Zn4(btz)6] metal-chain SBUs in the structure of compound 2 rather than [Zn9(btz)12] clusters. As shown in a, metal chains are interconnected by linear bcpt2– ligands to construct a 3-fold interpenetrated 3D framework (b). Noticeably, the existence of metal chains and interspersed structure improves the stability of the structure. Along the [101] direction, there exist 1D ultra-microporous channels (3.4 Å × 3.4 Å) exclusive of van der Waals radius (d). The Linear bcpt2– ligand can be viewed as a 2-connected node; the locations of carboxylate carbon atoms are regarded as vertices of zigzag ladder metal chains, and can be seen as a 4-connected node. Hence, compound 2 can be viewed as a 4-connected abw topology with a Schläfli symbol of {42·63·8} (c,e). The PLATON calculation indicates that the total solvent-accessible volume is 6585 Å3, which accounts for about 33.5% per unit cell volume.

PXRD patterns indicate the phase purity of the synthesized sample (Figure S2, Supporting Information). Unlike compound 1, structural analysis shows that there are 1D zigzag ladder [Zn4(btz)6] metal-chain SBUs in the structure of compound 2 rather than [Zn9(btz)12] clusters. As shown in a, metal chains are interconnected by linear bcpt2- ligands to construct a 3-fold interpenetrated 3D framework (b). Noticeably, the existence of metal chains and interspersed structure improves the stability of the structure. Along the [101] direction, there exist 1D ultra-microporous channels (3.4 Å × 3.4 Å) exclusive of van der Waals radius (d). The Linear bcpt2- ligand can be viewed as a 2-connected node; the locations of carboxylate carbon atoms are regarded as vertices of zigzag ladder metal chains, and can be seen as a 4-connected node. Hence, compound 2 can be viewed as a 4-connected abw topology with a Schläfli symbol of {42⋅63⋅8} (c,e). The PLATON calculation indicates that the total solvent-accessible volume is 6585 Å3, which accounts for about 33.5% per unit cell volume.

elements.content: Description of compound 2: (a) polyhedral view of the abw topology; (b) the 3D interpenetrated net of compound 2; (c) polyhedral view of the 3-fold interpenetrated net; (d) 1D ultra-microporous channels (3.4 Å × 3.4 Å); (e) topological illustration displayed by tiling.
elements.clean_text: 2  Description of compound 2: (a) polyhedral view of the abw topology; (b) the 3D interpenetrated net of compound 2; (c) polyhedral view of the 3-fold interpenetrated net; (d) 1D ultra-microporous channels (3.4 Å × 3.4 Å); (e) topological illustration displayed by tiling.

elements.content: TGA of two compounds was tested to explore their thermal stabilities (Figure S4, Supporting Information). For compound 1, the initial weight loss of 14.6% below 250 °C on account of the loss of guest solvents and compound 1 can stabilize to about 390 °C. Compound 2 can stabilize to about 435 °C with 15.1% weight loss below 205 °C belongs to the removal of DMF solvents. Obviously, two compounds exhibit good thermal stability.
elements.clean_text: TGA of two compounds was tested to explore their thermal stabilities (Figure S4, Supporting Information). For compound 1, the initial weight loss of 14.6% below 250 °C on account of the loss of guest solvents and compound 1 can stabilize to about 390 °C. Compound 2 can stabilize to about 435 °C with 15.1% weight loss below 205 °C belongs to the removal of DMF solvents. Obviously, two compounds exhibit good thermal stability.

elements.content: The porous property of compound 1 was probed by nitrogen adsorption measurement at 77 K. The sample was immersed in acetonitrile for about 72 h and then treated at 100 °C for 10 h under high vacuum. TGA analysis indicates that guest solvents are completely removed from the framework and the sample is fully activated. The PXRD patterns of activated, as-synthesized, and simulated samples are consistent, confirming that the framework of activated compound 1 has not changed (Figure S2, Supporting Information). N2 adsorption of the activated sample exhibits reversible type-I isotherm, which is characteristic of microporous materials (a). Interestingly, during the N2 adsorption process, compound 1 exhibits a rare adsorption behavior, the N2 uptake suddenly increases to 192 cm3 g–1 when the pressure reaches nearly 0.017 atm, which is due to the emergence of the gate-opening behavior. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area for compound 1 was measured to be 680 m2 g–1, which outdoes some reported Zn-cluster-based MOFs materials (Table S4, Supporting Information). The experimental pore volume of compound 1 is 0.34 cm3 g–1, which is almost the same as the theoretical pore volume of 0.35 cm3 g–1. The porosity and gate-opening behavior of compound 1 were further investigated, CO2 adsorption/desorption at 195 K was carried out. As shown in b, the CO2 adsorption isotherms clearly showed two steps. At nearly 0.15 atm, the amount of CO2 adsorption was 128 cm3 g–1 and the first step appears. When the pressure reaches 0.2 atm, there exist the second step and the amount suddenly increased to 162 cm3 g–1.
elements.clean_text:
Gas Adsorption Properties

The porous property of compound 1 was probed by nitrogen adsorption measurement at 77 K. The sample was immersed in acetonitrile for about 72 h and then treated at 100 °C for 10 h under high vacuum. TGA analysis indicates that guest solvents are completely removed from the framework and the sample is fully activated. The PXRD patterns of activated, as-synthesized, and simulated samples are consistent, confirming that the framework of activated compound 1 has not changed (Figure S2, Supporting Information). N2 adsorption of the activated sample exhibits reversible type-I isotherm, which is characteristic of microporous materials (a). Interestingly, during the N2 adsorption process, compound 1 exhibits a rare adsorption behavior, the N2 uptake suddenly increases to 192 cm3 g-1 when the pressure reaches nearly 0.017 atm, which is due to the emergence of the gate-opening behavior. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area for compound 1 was measured to be 680 m2 g-1, which outdoes some reported Zn-cluster-based MOFs materials (Table S4, Supporting Information). The experimental pore volume of compound 1 is 0.34 cm3 g-1, which is almost the same as the theoretical pore volume of 0.35 cm3 g-1. The porosity and gate-opening behavior of compound 1 were further investigated, CO2 adsorption/desorption at 195 K was carried out. As shown in b, the CO2 adsorption isotherms clearly showed two steps. At nearly 0.15 atm, the amount of CO2 adsorption was 128 cm3 g-1 and the first step appears. When the pressure reaches 0.2 atm, there exist the second step and the amount suddenly increased to 162 cm3 g-1.

elements.content: (a) N2 adsorption isotherms for compounds 1 and 2 at 77 K; (b) CO2 adsorption isotherms for compounds 1 and 2 at 195 K.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) N2 adsorption isotherms for compounds 1 and 2 at 77 K; (b) CO2 adsorption isotherms for compounds 1 and 2 at 195 K.

elements.content: For compound 2, the N2 adsorption isotherm was also carried out at 77 K. Because the size of the channel (3.4 Å) is smaller than that of the nitrogen molecule, there is no N2 adsorption (a). Taking into account the size of the carbon dioxide molecule, CO2 adsorption isotherm of compound 2 at 195 K was carried out (b). To our surprise, the isotherms at 195 K shows three distinct steps, the gate opening pressures are 0.4 and 0.65 atm, respectively. The phenomenon of gate-opening effect is attributed to the flexible nature of the interpenetrated frameworks. So far, many flexible materials with breathing behavior have been reported.
elements.clean_text: For compound 2, the N2 adsorption isotherm was also carried out at 77 K. Because the size of the channel (3.4 Å) is smaller than that of the nitrogen molecule, there is no N2 adsorption (a). Taking into account the size of the carbon dioxide molecule, CO2 adsorption isotherm of compound 2 at 195 K was carried out (b). To our surprise, the isotherms at 195 K shows three distinct steps, the gate opening pressures are 0.4 and 0.65 atm, respectively. The phenomenon of gate-opening effect is attributed to the flexible nature of the interpenetrated frameworks. So far, many flexible materials with breathing behavior have been reported.

elements.content: Before the further small-molecule gas adsorption measurements, the chemical stability of compounds 1 and 2 are investigated. Compound 1 was soaked in water, HCl (pH = 2) and NaOH (pH = 12) solutions for 24 h, respectively. As depicted in a, the PXRD patterns of compound 1 treated under different conditions coincide with that of pristine samples, which indicate that compound 1 has no phase transformation or framework collapse and still retains its crystallinity. N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of compound 1 treated under water, pH = 2 and pH = 12 solutions were carried out at 77 K, their BET surface areas are 662, 644 and 638 m2 g–1, respectively, these values are close to that of the pristine sample (680 m2 g–1), which further confirmed its stability under these environments (b). Moreover, compound 1 also exhibits notable stability in common organic solvents (such as acetonitrile, methanol, ethanol, acetone, chloroform, DMF, N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone, dimethyl sulfoxide, N,N-dimethylacetamide, N-methylformamide) (Figure S5, Supporting Information). Because of the chemical stability, compound 1 has potential probability for industrial applications. Furthermore, compound 2 also shows high chemical stability toward water, acidic and basic solutions (pH = 2 and pH = 12) and common organic solvents (ethanol, acetonitrile, acetone, dichloromethane, chloroform, DMF, N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone, dimethyl sulfoxide, N,N-dimethylacetamide, N-methylformamide) (Figure S5, Supporting Information).

As depicted in a, the PXRD patterns of compound 1 treated under different conditions coincide with that of pristine samples, which indicate that compound 1 has no phase transformation or framework collapse and still retains its crystallinity. N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of compound 1 treated under water, pH = 2 and pH = 12 solutions were carried out at 77 K, their BET surface areas are 662, 644 and 638 m2 g-1, respectively, these values are close to that of the pristine sample (680 m2 g-1), which further confirmed its stability under these environments (b). Moreover, compound 1 also exhibits notable stability in common organic solvents (such as acetonitrile, methanol, ethanol, acetone, chloroform, DMF, N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone, dimethyl sulfoxide, N,N-dimethylacetamide, N-methylformamide) (Figure S5, Supporting Information). Because of the chemical stability, compound 1 has potential probability for industrial applications. Furthermore, compound 2 also shows high chemical stability toward water, acidic and basic solutions (pH = 2 and pH = 12) and common organic solvents (ethanol, acetonitrile, acetone, dichloromethane, chloroform, DMF, N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone, dimethyl sulfoxide, N,N-dimethylacetamide, N-methylformamide) (Figure S5, Supporting Information).

elements.content: (a) PXRD patterns of compound 1 treated under water, acidic, and basic solutions; (b) N2 sorption isotherms of compound 1 after being treated under water, acidic, and basic solutions.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) PXRD patterns of compound 1 treated under water, acidic, and basic solutions; (b) N2 sorption isotherms of compound 1 after being treated under water, acidic, and basic solutions.

elements.content: The high surface area and chemical stability of compound 1 inspired us to explore its ability to capture small-molecule gas, such as CO2 and small-molecule hydrocarbon. The CO2 adsorption isotherms were carried out (a). The amount of CO2 adsorption is 61 and 37 cm3 g–1 at 273 and 298 K under 1 bar, respectively. Noticeably, compound 1 shows high CO2 adsorption among the Zn-cluster-based MOFs materials (Table S4, Supporting Information). At zero loading, Q st of compound 1 is 25 kJ mol–1 (Figure S6, Supporting Information), the value is comparable to that of water stable MOF JLU-Liu18, indicating the strong host–guest interactions. Furthermore, the CH4, C2H6, and C3H8 adsorption isotherms were carried out. The amount of CH4, C2H6, and C3H8 adsorption at 273 K under 1 bar is 17, 74, and 75 cm3 g–1, respectively. The amount of CH4, C2H6, and C3H8 adsorption at 298 K under 1 bar is 10, 48, and 56 cm3 g–1, respectively (). At zero coverage, Q st of CH4, C2H6, and C3H8 is 18, 36, and 32 kJ mol–1, respectively (Figure S6, Supporting Information). Interestingly, only C2H6 and C3H8 exhibit breathing behavior at 273 K, and the adsorption amount suddenly increases when pressure reaches 0.72 and 0.26 atm, respectively. For example, Matsuda and co-workers reported a [Mn­(bdc)­(dpe)] MOF, it exhibits breathing behavior for C2H2 adsorption but not for CO2 at low temperatures such as 246 K, which may be used for selective separation of CO2 over C2H2.
elements.clean_text: The high surface area and chemical stability of compound 1 inspired us to explore its ability to capture small-molecule gas, such as CO2 and small-molecule hydrocarbon. The CO2 adsorption isotherms were carried out (a). The amount of CO2 adsorption is 61 and 37 cm3 g-1 at 273 and 298 K under 1 bar, respectively. Noticeably, compound 1 shows high CO2 adsorption among the Zn-cluster-based MOFs materials (Table S4, Supporting Information). At zero loading, Q st of compound 1 is 25 kJ mol-1 (Figure S6, Supporting Information), the value is comparable to that of water stable MOF JLU-Liu18, indicating the strong host-guest interactions. Furthermore, the CH4, C2H6, and C3H8 adsorption isotherms were carried out. The amount of CH4, C2H6, and C3H8 adsorption at 273 K under 1 bar is 17, 74, and 75 cm3 g-1, respectively. The amount of CH4, C2H6, and C3H8 adsorption at 298 K under 1 bar is 10, 48, and 56 cm3 g-1, respectively (). At zero coverage, Q st of CH4, C2H6, and C3H8 is 18, 36, and 32 kJ mol-1, respectively (Figure S6, Supporting Information). Interestingly, only C2H6 and C3H8 exhibit breathing behavior at 273 K, and the adsorption amount suddenly increases when pressure reaches 0.72 and 0.26 atm, respectively. For example, Matsuda and co-workers reported a [Mn(bdc)(dpe)] MOF, it exhibits breathing behavior for C2H2 adsorption but not for CO2 at low temperatures such as 246 K, which may be used for selective separation of CO2 over C2H2.

elements.content: (a) CO2 and CH4 adsorption isotherms for compound 1; (b) the CO2/CH4 selectivity of compound 1 at 298 K; (c) C2H6 and (d) C3H8 adsorption isotherms for compound 1.
elements.clean_text: 5  (a) CO2 and CH4 adsorption isotherms for compound 1; (b) the CO2/CH4 selectivity of compound 1 at 298 K; (c) C2H6 and (d) C3H8 adsorption isotherms for compound 1.

elements.content: Furthermore, through ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST), the theoretical separation CO2, C2H6, and C3H8 over CH4 of compound 1 were performed. The adsorption isotherms at 298 K were fitted by using the dual-site Langmuir–Freundlich equation, and then the multicomponent adsorption with IAST was predicted by using the fitting parameters (Table S5, Supporting Information). It turns out that the CO2/CH4 selectivity for compound 1 is 5.2 (0.5:0.5) and 5.7 (0.05:0.95) at 298 K and 1 bar, respectively (b), which is similar to the value of ZJU-60 (0.5:0.5). The separation of CO2/CH4 of compound 1 is attributed to the effect of Lewis basic sites from N-rich ligands, which effectively improve the interaction between CO2 molecules and the host framework. In the case of equimolar mixtures, the C2H6/CH4 and C3H8/CH4 selectivity is 13 and 52 at 298 K and 1 bar (Figure S7, Supporting Information), respectively. The separation of C2H6/CH4 and C3H8/CH4 are attributed to the strength of the interaction between the small gases and the framework, which can be observed by adsorption enthalpy (Q st = 18, 36 and 32 kJ mol–1 for CH4, C2H6, and C3H8, respectively). All experimental results indicate that compound 1 has good ability to selectively separate small gases.
elements.clean_text: Furthermore, through ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST), the theoretical separation CO2, C2H6, and C3H8 over CH4 of compound 1 were performed. The adsorption isotherms at 298 K were fitted by using the dual-site Langmuir-Freundlich equation, and then the multicomponent adsorption with IAST was predicted by using the fitting parameters (Table S5, Supporting Information). It turns out that the CO2/CH4 selectivity for compound 1 is 5.2 (0.5:0.5) and 5.7 (0.05:0.95) at 298 K and 1 bar, respectively (b), which is similar to the value of ZJU-60 (0.5:0.5). The separation of CO2/CH4 of compound 1 is attributed to the effect of Lewis basic sites from N-rich ligands, which effectively improve the interaction between CO2 molecules and the host framework. In the case of equimolar mixtures, the C2H6/CH4 and C3H8/CH4 selectivity is 13 and 52 at 298 K and 1 bar (Figure S7, Supporting Information), respectively. The separation of C2H6/CH4 and C3H8/CH4 are attributed to the strength of the interaction between the small gases and the framework, which can be observed by adsorption enthalpy (Q st = 18, 36 and 32 kJ mol-1 for CH4, C2H6, and C3H8, respectively). All experimental results indicate that compound 1 has good ability to selectively separate small gases.

elements.content: In summary, two stable MOFs, compounds 1 and 2, based on [Zn x (btz) y ] SBUs have been successfully constructed by adopting the mixed ligand approach. Both compounds exhibit high thermal and chemical stability, especially compounds 1 and 2 shows excellent stability in pH = 2 and pH = 12 solutions. In the process of gas adsorption, compounds 1 and 2 all exhibit breathing behavior. In addition, compound 1 has good sorption ability for small gases and good selectivity to separate CO2 from CH4. Because of chemical stability of compound 1, such porous material may be applied to separate gases in practical industrial applications.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, two stable MOFs, compounds 1 and 2, based on [Zn x (btz) y ] SBUs have been successfully constructed by adopting the mixed ligand approach. Both compounds exhibit high thermal and chemical stability, especially compounds 1 and 2 shows excellent stability in pH = 2 and pH = 12 solutions. In the process of gas adsorption, compounds 1 and 2 all exhibit breathing behavior. In addition, compound 1 has good sorption ability for small gases and good selectivity to separate CO2 from CH4. Because of chemical stability of compound 1, such porous material may be applied to separate gases in practical industrial applications.

cln_elements.content:
The mixture of zinc nitrate hexahydrate (13.6 mg, 0.045 mmol), Hbtz (11 mg, 0.092 mmol), H2atdbc (5 mg, 0.015 mmol), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) (1 mL) and acetic acid (15 μL) was placed in a tightly capped 10 mL vial, then heated at 85 °C for 12 h and 105 °C for 1 day. Colorless block crystals were obtained and immersed in fresh DMF and desiccated under air conditions [yield 60% based on zinc nitrate hexahydrate]. Elemental analysis (wt %) for compound 1: calcd: C, 45.6; H, 3.7; N, 21.0. Found: C, 46.0; H, 3.5; N, 20.9.

Synthesis of Compound <bold>2</bold>

The mixture of zinc nitrate hexahydrate (14 mg, 0.047 mmol), Hbtz (22 mg, 0.184 mmol), H2bcpt (5 mg, 0.016 mmol), DMF (1 mL), and acetic acid (20 μL) was placed in a tightly capped 10 mL vial, then heated at 85 °C for 12 h and 105 °C for 3 days. Colorless block crystals were obtained and immersed in fresh DMF and desiccated under air conditions [yield 60% based on zinc nitrate hexahydrate]. Elemental analysis (wt %) for compound 2: calcd: C, 48.9; H, 3.6; N, 22.4. Found: C, 48.8; H, 3.5; N, 22.3.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Compound 1 

The mixture of zinc nitrate hexahydrate (13.6 mg, 0.045 mmol), Hbtz (11 mg, 0.092 mmol), H2atdbc (5 mg, 0.015 mmol), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) (1 mL) and acetic acid (15 μL) was placed in a tightly capped 10 mL vial, then heated at 85 °C for 12 h and 105 °C for 1 day. Colorless block crystals were obtained and immersed in fresh DMF and desiccated under air conditions [yield 60% based on zinc nitrate hexahydrate]. Elemental analysis (wt %) for compound 1: calcd: C, 45.6; H, 3.7; N, 21.0. Found: C, 46.0; H, 3.5; N, 20.9.

Synthesis of Compound 2 

The mixture of zinc nitrate hexahydrate (14 mg, 0.047 mmol), Hbtz (22 mg, 0.184 mmol), H2bcpt (5 mg, 0.016 mmol), DMF (1 mL), and acetic acid (20 μL) was placed in a tightly capped 10 mL vial, then heated at 85 °C for 12 h and 105 °C for 3 days. Colorless block crystals were obtained and immersed in fresh DMF and desiccated under air conditions [yield 60% based on zinc nitrate hexahydrate]. Elemental analysis (wt %) for compound 2: calcd: C, 48.9; H, 3.6; N, 22.4. Found: C, 48.8; H, 3.5; N, 22.3.

cln_elements.content:
TGA of two compounds was tested to explore their thermal stabilities (Figure S4, Supporting Information). For compound 1, the initial weight loss of 14.6% below 250 °C on account of the loss of guest solvents and compound 1 can stabilize to about 390 °C. Compound 2 can stabilize to about 435 °C with 15.1% weight loss below 205 °C belongs to the removal of DMF solvents. Obviously, two compounds exhibit good thermal stability.

Gas Adsorption Properties

The porous property of compound 1 was probed by nitrogen adsorption measurement at 77 K. The sample was immersed in acetonitrile for about 72 h and then treated at 100 °C for 10 h under high vacuum. TGA analysis indicates that guest solvents are completely removed from the framework and the sample is fully activated. The PXRD patterns of activated, as-synthesized, and simulated samples are consistent, confirming that the framework of activated compound 1 has not changed (Figure S2, Supporting Information). N2 adsorption of the activated sample exhibits reversible type-I isotherm, which is characteristic of microporous materials (a). Interestingly, during the N2 adsorption process, compound 1 exhibits a rare adsorption behavior, the N2 uptake suddenly increases to 192 cm3 g–1 when the pressure reaches nearly 0.017 atm, which is due to the emergence of the gate-opening behavior. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area for compound 1 was measured to be 680 m2 g–1, which outdoes some reported Zn-cluster-based MOFs materials (Table S4, Supporting Information). The experimental pore volume of compound 1 is 0.34 cm3 g–1, which is almost the same as the theoretical pore volume of 0.35 cm3 g–1. The porosity and gate-opening behavior of compound 1 were further investigated, CO2 adsorption/desorption at 195 K was carried out. As shown in b, the CO2 adsorption isotherms clearly showed two steps. At nearly 0.15 atm, the amount of CO2 adsorption was 128 cm3 g–1 and the first step appears. When the pressure reaches 0.2 atm, there exist the second step and the amount suddenly increased to 162 cm3 g–1.

The high surface area and chemical stability of compound 1 inspired us to explore its ability to capture small-molecule gas, such as CO2 and small-molecule hydrocarbon. The CO2 adsorption isotherms were carried out (a). The amount of CO2 adsorption is 61 and 37 cm3 g–1 at 273 and 298 K under 1 bar, respectively. Noticeably, compound 1 shows high CO2 adsorption among the Zn-cluster-based MOFs materials (Table S4, Supporting Information). At zero loading, Q st of compound 1 is 25 kJ mol–1 (Figure S6, Supporting Information), the value is comparable to that of water stable MOF JLU-Liu18, indicating the strong host–guest interactions. Furthermore, the CH4, C2H6, and C3H8 adsorption isotherms were carried out. The amount of CH4, C2H6, and C3H8 adsorption at 273 K under 1 bar is 17, 74, and 75 cm3 g–1, respectively. The amount of CH4, C2H6, and C3H8 adsorption at 298 K under 1 bar is 10, 48, and 56 cm3 g–1, respectively (). At zero coverage, Q st of CH4, C2H6, and C3H8 is 18, 36, and 32 kJ mol–1, respectively (Figure S6, Supporting Information). Interestingly, only C2H6 and C3H8 exhibit breathing behavior at 273 K, and the adsorption amount suddenly increases when pressure reaches 0.72 and 0.26 atm, respectively. For example, Matsuda and co-workers reported a [Mn­(bdc)­(dpe)] MOF, it exhibits breathing behavior for C2H2 adsorption but not for CO2 at low temperatures such as 246 K, which may be used for selective separation of CO2 over C2H2.

TGA of two compounds was tested to explore their thermal stabilities (Figure S4, Supporting Information). For compound 1, the initial weight loss of 14.6% below 250 °C on account of the loss of guest solvents and compound 1 can stabilize to about 390 °C. Compound 2 can stabilize to about 435 °C with 15.1% weight loss below 205 °C belongs to the removal of DMF solvents. Obviously, two compounds exhibit good thermal stability.

Gas Adsorption Properties

The porous property of compound 1 was probed by nitrogen adsorption measurement at 77 K. The sample was immersed in acetonitrile for about 72 h and then treated at 100 °C for 10 h under high vacuum. TGA analysis indicates that guest solvents are completely removed from the framework and the sample is fully activated. The PXRD patterns of activated, as-synthesized, and simulated samples are consistent, confirming that the framework of activated compound 1 has not changed (Figure S2, Supporting Information). N2 adsorption of the activated sample exhibits reversible type-I isotherm, which is characteristic of microporous materials (a). Interestingly, during the N2 adsorption process, compound 1 exhibits a rare adsorption behavior, the N2 uptake suddenly increases to 192 cm3 g-1 when the pressure reaches nearly 0.017 atm, which is due to the emergence of the gate-opening behavior. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area for compound 1 was measured to be 680 m2 g-1, which outdoes some reported Zn-cluster-based MOFs materials (Table S4, Supporting Information). The experimental pore volume of compound 1 is 0.34 cm3 g-1, which is almost the same as the theoretical pore volume of 0.35 cm3 g-1. The porosity and gate-opening behavior of compound 1 were further investigated, CO2 adsorption/desorption at 195 K was carried out. As shown in b, the CO2 adsorption isotherms clearly showed two steps. At nearly 0.15 atm, the amount of CO2 adsorption was 128 cm3 g-1 and the first step appears. When the pressure reaches 0.2 atm, there exist the second step and the amount suddenly increased to 162 cm3 g-1.

The high surface area and chemical stability of compound 1 inspired us to explore its ability to capture small-molecule gas, such as CO2 and small-molecule hydrocarbon. The CO2 adsorption isotherms were carried out (a). The amount of CO2 adsorption is 61 and 37 cm3 g-1 at 273 and 298 K under 1 bar, respectively. Noticeably, compound 1 shows high CO2 adsorption among the Zn-cluster-based MOFs materials (Table S4, Supporting Information). At zero loading, Q st of compound 1 is 25 kJ mol-1 (Figure S6, Supporting Information), the value is comparable to that of water stable MOF JLU-Liu18, indicating the strong host-guest interactions. Furthermore, the CH4, C2H6, and C3H8 adsorption isotherms were carried out. The amount of CH4, C2H6, and C3H8 adsorption at 273 K under 1 bar is 17, 74, and 75 cm3 g-1, respectively. The amount of CH4, C2H6, and C3H8 adsorption at 298 K under 1 bar is 10, 48, and 56 cm3 g-1, respectively (). At zero coverage, Q st of CH4, C2H6, and C3H8 is 18, 36, and 32 kJ mol-1, respectively (Figure S6, Supporting Information). Interestingly, only C2H6 and C3H8 exhibit breathing behavior at 273 K, and the adsorption amount suddenly increases when pressure reaches 0.72 and 0.26 atm, respectively. For example, Matsuda and co-workers reported a [Mn(bdc)(dpe)] MOF, it exhibits breathing behavior for C2H2 adsorption but not for CO2 at low temperatures such as 246 K, which may be used for selective separation of CO2 over C2H2.

metadata.title:
Two Stable Zn-Cluster-Based Metal–Organic
Frameworks with Breathing Behavior: Synthesis, Structure, and Adsorption
Properties
